;看起来就像一场普通的中国北方乡村婚礼，主持人致辞7月7日，在数十位亲友面前。

;

;“让我们为今天举行隆重婚礼的新人庆祝，祝他们一生幸福”，主持人说道。

;

; p>;

;但“新人”的婚姻只能维持一天。

;

;《凤凰周刊》报道称，河北省农村地区单身人士“一日婚”正在盛行。男人死后渴望进入祖坟。

;

;在一些地区，迷信认为，太穷而无法吸引妻子的男人（通常被轻蔑地称为“光棍”或“光棍”）不能被埋葬在坟墓中。

;

;这可能会破坏家族的风水，并诅咒他们一代又一代的单身男性。

;

;许多人认为，被允许进入家族的男性祖坟将由家族的子孙看守，并在来世享受他们为他们烧的纸钱和其他物品。

;

;据报道，一日婚姻在五六区流行起来。几年前。它们已经成为曾经盛行的鬼婚的替代方案，在鬼婚中，一方或双方都已死亡。

;

;一位姓吴的媒婆经营着一家安排一日婚的生意，她说她有几个“专业的”媒人。

;

;她向男士收取 3,600 元（500 美元）租用新娘的费用，并收取 1,000 元作为经纪费。

;

;“新娘”参加婚礼并参观她说，大多数“新娘”都是外地的保姆或按摩师，因为许多人担心这项生意可能会损害她们的声誉

;

;7月7日婚礼上的假新娘田说，她需要钱来养活丈夫和儿子。她是一名按摩院老板，每月收入几千元。

;

;田说，她的家人并不知道她打工的事，因为她在打工时化浓妆、戴假发，试图隐藏自己的身份。

;

;她于 2021 年开始为吴工作，48 岁，是媒人最年轻的“新娘”。

;

;7 月 7 日婚礼中的新郎姓宋，名叫一日结婚“一桩生意”，因为他不需要支付聘礼——在该省通常价格在 10 万元人民币（14,000 美元）左右。

;

;吴说，她正在帮助假新郎，

;

;“除了钱，没有什么是真实的”，她说。

;

;在大陆的社交媒体上，一日婚被比作一场婚礼。极端版的男女朋友租赁服务，在寻求缓解父母婚姻压力的年轻人中很流行。

;

;一些社交网络观察人士对男性对进入祖坟的痴迷感到震惊。< /p>;

;“首先，我不明白单身不能进祖坟的传统。第二，既然你已经不活了，何必那么在意进入其中呢？”一位评论者说。

;

;“我见过很多次骗人的人，但骗鬼是新鲜事，”另一位评论者说。

;

;“他们说婚姻是爱情的坟墓。这是真的，”第三个打趣道。

;由于夏季单产下降，中国今年粮食产量不佳分析人士警告称，更多极端天气即将到来。

;

;特别令人担忧的是占中国全年粮食产量 75% 的秋收，他们表示，由于天气原因，秋季收成可能会减产。恶劣天气——这是2018年以来中国夏季收成首次下降的主要原因。

;

;今年夏天，中国已经面临罕见的恶劣天气，随之而来的干旱、洪涝和农作物减产等风险也随之增加。西北农林科技大学农业经济学教授霍学熙表示，“考虑到预计的气候破坏风险，今年的粮食产量恐怕很难维持去年的水平。”他说。国家统计局周末表示，夏季粮食产量下降 0.9%，主要原因是在收获前夕，长时间降雨袭击了种植面积最大的省份河南的成熟小麦。

;

;截至去年今年，面对全球不确定性，中国高度重视粮食安全，粮食产量连续八年保持在6.5亿吨以上。根据去年发布的中央政府农业五年计划，北京的目标是至少保持这一水平，并到 2025 年将其提高到 7 亿吨。

;

;但今年夏天，中国已创下了最高纪录。国家气候中心本月早些时候在微信帖子中表示，至少自 1961 年以来，气温达到 35 摄氏度（95 华氏度）或以上的天数。

;

;自 7 月 3 日起，世界经历了历史上最热的一周-10，根据世界气象组织的数据，在厄尔尼诺气候事件开始时，有人说这将使今年成为世界有记录以来最热的一年。

;

;中国北部和中部部分地区的幼苗已经显示农业农村部在本月初的一篇文章中警告说，自上月底以来，受热浪影响，经济增长出现疲软迹象，“给秋收带来严峻挑战”。

;

;农业农村部表示，已责成当地

;

;中国科学院遗传与发育生物学研究所研究员朱震表示，极端气温无论是过低还是过高，会损害作物生长并导致产量低下。

;

;“我们或许能够缓解干旱和洪水，但在帮助作物应对极端温度方面几乎无能为力，除了培育更能抵抗高温或干旱的新物种。寒冷，”他说。

;

;对美国和泰国农民的警告：到 2032 年，中国将种植 90% 的粮食

;

;在这方面，“中国已经取得了成就”实验室，但广泛应用仍需要时间”，他说。

;

;霍说，中国需要改进天气和气候模式的预测，以便人们更好地应对恶劣天气。

;

;“在苹果生产基地陕西，由于预报不够及时和准确，农民仍然遭受损失。”他说。

;

;中国完成了首次全国自然灾害调查经过三年的调查，评估了气候变化对人类健康和粮食生产的影响，并于 2 月份发布了风险报告。

;

;超过 70% 的城市以及一半以上的人口都位于这些地区应急管理部下属的《中国应急管理报》今年 5 月表示，无论是气象还是地质灾害，这些地区都被认为是发生自然灾害的风险相对较高的地区。

;一位世界知名病毒学家呼吁全球科学家联手抗击新冠病毒哥伦比亚大学教授 David Ho 告诉《华盛顿邮报》，香港大学 (HKU) 和北京清华大学他们对他建立“流行病研究联盟”的计划表示支持。

;

;这位因发现鸡尾酒抗逆转录病毒疗法治疗艾滋病的功效而受到赞誉的学者周六表示，他正在与墨尔本大学关于加入该联盟的信息。

;

;“我们希望确定流行病最重要的病毒威胁是什么，例如我们所经历的冠状病毒、流感病毒和我们所说的副粘病毒，”他说。 “所有这些都可以很容易地通过呼吸道在人与人之间传播，因此传播速度非常快。

;

;“一旦我们确定了最重要的威胁，我们就可以开始更详细地研究它们，以了解如果我们能够开发药物、抗体和疫苗，并做好准备。他们中的一些人没有任何这些，因此，如果其中一种成为引起病毒的流行病，我们可以让他们做好准备。”

;

;何是最早识别艾滋病毒并绘制图表的科学家之一它对患者的影响。 1996 年，他是第一位被《时代》杂志评为年度人物的医生，因为他在艾滋病治疗方面的工作有助于提高生存率。

;

;这位病毒学家与香港大学袁国勇教授合作，当时2003 年，该市爆发了严重急性呼吸系统综合症 (Sars)，两人测试了抗病毒药物以改善治疗选择。

;

;何后来在 Covid-19 期间在哥伦比亚大学建立了一个多学科专家团队

;

;香港领导人展望医疗保健的未来以及 Covid-19 带来的医疗威胁

;

;成立联盟的想法是受到他说，随着最近的大流行开始减弱，四个研究所的科学家之间就未来的威胁进行了对话。

;

;“我们不想重蹈过去 3.5 年的覆辙，所以我们想做好更好的准备，”他说。 “我们预计会出现另一场大流行病和另一场大流行病，但没有专家可以告诉你何时何地或具体是哪一部分。

;

;“随着环境的变化，人类与各种动物物种相互作用的动态正在发生变化，并可能导致更多病毒从动物传播到人类，其中一些可能具有大流行的潜力。”

;

;Covid-19 大流行于 2020 年开始，已导致全球确诊病例超过 7.67 亿例，死亡人数超过 695 万人。

;

;剑桥大学 2020 年预测，到 2025 年，这一流行病将给全球经济造成 82 万亿美元的损失。

;

;计划加入该联盟的香港大学袁教授周一表示，尽管其他科学家也在组建团队，但何领导的团队具有独特的优势，因为它吸引了太平洋彼岸的专家。

;

;他解释说，过去全球流行病的数据表明此类事件正变得越来越频繁并主要起源于环洋地区。

;

;袁补充说，每个参与机构提供的不同专业对于为未来的疫情爆发做好准备也至关重要。

;

;“香港大学最擅长识别新病毒，就像我们在人类和动物身上发现了 80 多种新病毒一样。何的团队专注于免疫学。他们对抗病毒耐药性有特殊的理解，”他说。 “对于清华大学来说，他们做了很多研究，致力于了解抗体的结构。他们还创造了针对 Covid-19 的抗体，并已商业化。

;

;“澳大利亚的研究人员在发病机制方面拥有专业知识。如果不了解这些领域中的任何一个，就不可能为大流行做好准备。”

;

;下一次大流行？世卫组织正在制定需要关注的病原体清单

;

;Yuen 补充说，组建官方联盟将使研究成果的共享变得更加容易，并将此类努力描述为“互补”。

;

;“我们的技术交流，病毒株和标本将会更加接近，”他说。 “我们将能够进行分工并更快地取得成果。过去，我们不知道其他人在做什么。”

;

;这位香港大学学者表示，该联盟的第一步将是识别源自动物的病毒，这些病毒可能会传染给人类。他还预计未来可能会有更多来自欧洲等地区的专家加入。

;

;世界需要中国的参与，以避免另一场大流行灾难

;

;何说香港和内地已经合作过去 20 年来，香港在抗击流行病方面发挥了重要作用，预计这一作用将随着时间的推移而增强。

;

;“香港先是面对非典，然后又面对 H5N1。我亲自见证了这里专业知识的扩展以及科学家和政府官员的更大承诺。这种进步是巨大的、令人钦佩的，”他指的是 1997 年爆发的禽流感。

;

;“中国大陆的机构也是如此。比较 Covid-19 和 Sars 的反应有白天和黑夜的差异。现在的专业知识更加丰富，并将继续增长。我们在美国工作，常常过来帮忙。而现在情况就大不一样了。我们来合作、互相帮助。”

;香港十四年来首次放宽按揭政策，尚未给全城带来欢乐二手房市场自7月7日推出以来的10天里，信心指数持平，最大的10个住宅小区的周末销售量已连续15周保持在个位数。

;

;二级市场销售量仅有5个利嘉阁地产 (Ricacorp Properties) 的数据显示，周末的成交量较上周六至周日下降了 44%。

;

;同时，米德兰信心指数 (Midland Confidence Index) 反映了已出售房屋的业主的信心周一，待售房屋价格环比持平，为 59.5 点。

;

;美联地产首席分析师 Buggle Lau 表示，房主们正在采取观望态度。

;

;房屋不冷不热

;

;“抵押贷款宽松是有帮助的，但不会立即产生效果，因为房地产市场仍面临多重阻力，包括加息和短期融资。”刘说。

;

;本月早些时候，香港金融管理局 (HKMA) 自 2009 年以来首次放宽抵押贷款规则，以使首次购房者和想要升级住房的人更容易借贷。更大的房屋。

;

;在多重阻力下香港房价进一步下跌：仲量联行

;

;此举激起了潜在购房者和现有业主的兴趣，但不会对房价产生太大影响经纪人和银行家表示，整体房地产市场前景。

;

;市场情绪持续疲软，因为购房者对利率预计将再次上升持谨慎态度。

;

;“购房者不会进入刘说，房地产市场需要时间来消化房贷放松政策。

;

;香港花旗在周一发布的一份报告中表示，抵押贷款变化对房地产市场的影响有限

;

;一旦每周二次成交量持续保持在较低水平，就表明房价调整期的开始。该银行表示，这一轮调整预计将至少持续到 2023 年底，“因为我们认为整体需求弱于我们已经看跌的假设”。

;

;“美国加息步伐要快得多花旗补充道：“降息将提振住房需求，但这不是花旗对 2024 年联邦基金利率预测的内部观点。”

;

;尽管美联储在 6 月份暂停了加息，但很可能会恢复其行动本月控制通胀。在美联储在连续十次加息后采取错开进一步加息的举措后，金管局还于 6 月份暂停加息，这是自 2022 年 3 月以来的首次，将香港基本利率维持在 5.5%。

;

;香港下半年租金和租赁活动预计将上升：高纬环球

;

;但香港的抵押贷款利率已从加息周期前的 1.5% 翻倍多至 3.5%。根据美联物业的数据，这意味着 30 年内贷款价值比为 90% 的 600 万港元（766,640 美元）公寓的每月按揭付款已飙升 30.1% 至 25,461 港元。

;

;此外，代理商称，房主不愿意降低要价。

;

;“买家和卖家之间存在拉锯战，”利嘉阁首席执行官刘威利 (Willy Liu) 表示。业主调价幅度未达到购房者预期，二级市场交易受阻。

;

;借贷成本上升，6月成交量、成交额下降

;

; Midland的Lau表示，整个二级市场不存在所谓的降价，除非一些业主在等钱或在短时间内移民。 “这就是为什么二级市场如此安静，周末只有很少的交易，”他补充道。

;

;中原地产编制的中原城市领先指数，衡量居住价格的指标周五报 165.18，周环比下跌 0.3%，创 10 周新低。

;

;二级市场销售疲软也受到香港新房供过于求的影响，香港新房供应过剩也影响了二级市场销售疲软。吸收需求。

;夏作权，一位中国亿万富翁投资者，靠着曾经很小的电池发家致富制造商比亚迪不太确定中国是否有能力在不久的将来取得 OpenAI 的 ChatGPT 等重大技术突破。

;

;虽然 1995 年对比亚迪（现在是全球最大的电动汽车制造商）的投资为他赢得了巨额回报夏认为基础研究的缺乏或成熟的资本市场是中国实现技术突破的障碍。

;

;“我不认为中国能突然产生ChatGPT级别的应用或技术， ”夏周五在上海高级金融学院在香港举办的行业论坛间隙告诉《南华早报》。

;

;“中国仍然缺乏很多基本的东西，”他说。 “例如，某些基础算法是美国的。芯片是美国的，很多关键的工业软件和硬件都是美国的。”

;

;夏仍然是他共同创立的电动汽车巨头的非执行董事，一直在经营自己的技术投资公司正轩投资自 2003 年以来，据《福布斯》报道，他的净资产为 37 亿美元。

;

;根据公司的财务报告，正轩专注于先进制造、人工智能 (AI)、机器人、新能源和半导体等高科技领域。网站。它支持了包括火箭制造商零壹空间和人形机器人制造商优必选在内的中国公司，后者于今年早些时候申请在香港上市。

;

;不过，夏的投资公司在投资中国初创企业时仍保持谨慎态度。他说，研究大型语言模型 (LLM) 的技术是支持类似 ChatGPT 服务的技术。

;

;希望加入生成式人工智能竞赛的中国初创企业面临着该国不发达的资本市场，夏表示，大多数投资机构和政府支持的基金对于投入数十亿美元犹豫不决，或者等待十多年才能让公司取得成功。

;

;“该领域的根本性创新技术很难实现人工智能将在短期内走出中国，”他说。 “所以我们对投资类似ChatGPT的服务不太抱有希望。”

;中国的人工智能市场继续吸引着知名人士。著名风险投资家、谷歌中国前总裁李开复本月早些时候推出了他的新公司零壹万物，旨在培养自己的法学硕士。

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 08:20:02 +0800 To put wind back in Hong Kong’s sails, youth outreach must go full speed aheadhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3227942/put-wind-back-hong-kongs-sails-youth-outreach-must-go-full-speed-ahead?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;在香港努力引导青年人的同时，行政长官约翰的到来令人鼓舞李家超迅速解决根本问题。政府在去年12月公布的青年发展蓝图和设立青年事务专员这一新职位中阐明了这一意图。接触和问责的轮廓一目了然。

;

;该文件的前言引用了习近平主席在香港回归中国25周年之际的讲话：“香港繁荣昌盛”它的年轻人蓬勃发展；年轻人全面发展，香港才能发展；只有年轻人有良好的职业前景，香港才有光明的未来。”

;

;蓝图的四个参与领域——探索、希望、赋权和贡献——的核心是培育“新青年” ”。”。

;

;反复出现的主题是国民教育，抛开革命术语不谈，国民教育并不例外。所有国家都为自己的成就感到自豪。然而，频繁的强调显示了与城市年轻人打交道时的不安。

;

;这种做法确实存在从有用的多渠道对话滑向尖锐的自上而下的教条的危险。历史表明，随着时间的推移，爱国主义会随着意识、参与和归属感的增强而被吸收。

;

;中国历史必须成为课程的一部分，因为事实而不是情感刺激，教育必须注重普通话和英语”重新定位。与任何地方的青少年一样，成年意味着挑战权威、寻求答案和拓展界限。

;

;2019-2020 年发生的事件是不可避免的历史（领土被中国吞并）与天真的碰撞。如果青少年对“祖国”有真诚的热情，那么明确的定义就是香港。早在 1976 年，澳大利亚记者理查德·休斯 (Richard Hughes) 就在书中将香港描述为“借来的地方，借来的时间”。

;

;现在，香港政府有责任激励年轻人。有相当多的工具可供使用。该蓝图概述了职业选择，其中一些在大湾区、冒险培训、职业教育以及国际和内地的实习和学生交流。它计划提供更多经济适用房和扩大青年旅舍计划。它希望鼓励社区服务和志愿精神，同时培养对国家认同、《基本法》和中国宪法的理解。

;

;年轻的城市唤起活力、乐观和活力的愿景。习是对的。香港和中国一样，正在老龄化。青年的外展活动和激励不仅仅是一种社交礼仪，对于让香港重新扬帆起航也至关重要。来自中国大陆的稳定移民最终将带来年轻的求职者，帮助他们重建进取的态度。

;

;香港的年轻人才是必须战略性培养的力量

;

;概述计划last year, Secretary for Home and Youth Affairs Alice Mak Mei-kuen said the idea is to create a “positive mindset”. Plans included launching a youth network and app for young people to plug into opportunities.

;

;Importantly, there appears to be some give for the disgruntled rump. “I believe that once [the youth] understand it, of course, they can continue their criticism, but at least they will have the message,” Mak said. It appears the government is willing to listen and engage, something the previous administration failed to do.

;

;Painting a positive future and providing tools for “upward mobility” is the right way to proceed rather than a heavy-handed approach. Law and order eruptions are often symptoms of a deeper disconnect.

;

;On the leadership side, teachers have a freshly defined code of conduct requiring them to act as role models, working with probity, integrity, and adherence to the rule of law.

;

;This is an opportune time for minorities, be they of Indian, Pakistani, Filipino or Indonesian descent, to be integrated into the broader population. Their histories are closely intertwined with the city. As traders, merchants, labourers, domestic helpers, investors and members of the constabulary, they have all played a part in the making of Hong Kong. Cultural diversity enriches and strengthens a “world city” which, by definition, cannot be monocultural.

;

;Yet, whereas Singapore has done much to weld its Chinese, Malay and Indian populations with cheery campaigns and artfully mixing communities in public housing, Hong Kong has little to show in this regard. Many Hongkongers are still mystified by turbaned Sikhs, unaware of Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, and quite oblivious to the culinary delights of the Muslim Eid celebrations.

;

;These minorities are the ones most threatened by the city's language policy. They require access to vocational training and an education system that does not favour those who speak Chinese as a first language.

;

;They are a bridge to South and Southeast Asia. India was Hong Kong's eighth-largest trading partner last year. Singapore ranked fourth, Malaysia ninth, and Thailand tenth, with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations accounting for 13.2 per cent of all merchandise trade.

;

;The government cannot afford to lose talent. The brain drain must be reversed and Hong Kong's youth encouraged to see themselves as impactful stakeholders.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Brace for more mortgage pain as Hong Kong lenders seen lifting prime rates with the Fed odds-on to tighten policy againhttps://www.scmp.com/business/banking-finance/article/3228013/brace-more-mortgage-pain-hong-kong-lenders-seen-lifting-prime-rates-fed-odds-tighten-policy-again?utm_source=rss_feed

;Hong Kong's biggest commercial banks are expected to raise borrowing costs next week to ease their funding pressure, analysts said, with the Federal Reserve odds-on to resume its policy tightening path after a pause in June.

;

;That would deliver a blow to consumers servicing HK$1.83 trillion (US$232 billion) of outstanding home mortgages, as well as delay a recovery in the city's real estate market and economy. The upshot is that it could help stem capital flight to higher-yielding US dollar assets.

;

;HSBC, Standard Chartered, Bank of China (Hong Kong) (BOCHK) and their peers are likely to bump up their prime rates by 12.5 basis points to 25 basis points, to the highest level last seen in February 2008, according to 11 of the 13 analysts surveyed by the Post on Monday. Two predicted no change.

;

;All 13 agreed the US central bank will lift its target rate by 25 basis points at its July 25-26 policy-setting meeting. Contracts on Fed fund futures implied a 96 per cent chance of a hike this month, while the odds are less than even for the other three remaining meetings in 2023.

;

;“Hong Kong's interbank liquidity is tight, the one-month Hibor stays at an uncomfortably high level,” said Desmond Tjiang, chief investment officer for equities at BEA Union Investment, which manages about US$7.3 billion of assets. “Banks will need to follow the US and raise their prime rates, albeit by a smaller magnitude.”

;

;The Hong Kong interbank offered rate, or Hibor, is the rate at which banks lend to each other, ranging from overnight to 12-month periods. The one-month rate, a benchmark for pricing home mortgages, was quoted at 4.96 per cent on Friday, versus 3.41 per cent in early May.

;

;The three-month rate, a reference for corporate loans, has risen to 5 per cent from 3.71 per cent over the same period, while the 12-month Hibor climbed to 5.19 per cent from 4.4 per cent, according to data published by the Hong Kong Association of Banks.

;

;The one-month Hibor-Libor gap stands at 34 basis points in favour of US dollar rates. The Hong Kong dollar has traded near the weak side of its HK$7.75-7.85 trading band for most of the past 12 months, prompting market intervention and depleting the city's aggregate balance by 80 per cent to just under HK$45 billion.

;

;Hong Kong emerged from a recession in the first quarter, when the economy expanded 2.7 per cent, aided by a swift end to zero-Covid curbs. Gross domestic product shrank by more than 4 per cent in each of the two preceding quarters.

;

;Hong Kong earlier this month loosened mortgage financing rules in the biggest market support move since 2009 by allowing first-time homebuyers and upgraders to borrow more against the value of their homes to help shore up the market.

;

;“It is not good for Hong Kong's economic recovery,” said Samuel Tse, an economist and strategist at DBS Bank in Hong Kong, who expects local banks to raise their prime rates by 25 basis points. “Rate hikes will hurt homebuyers.”

;

;The number of property transactions fell 10 per cent in June from a month earlier, sliding to a five-month low of 4,777 worth HK$293.1 billion, according to data released by the Land Registry. Home prices have weakened 15.9 per cent from a peak 20 months ago, and could lose as much as 8 per cent in 2023, according to JLL, a property consultancy.

;

;Hong Kong part of global financial system, not just gateway to China: HKMA CEO

;

;In the Monday survey, five of the 11 analysts expected local banks to raise their prime rates by 12.5 basis points, while three predicted a range of 12.5 to 25 basis points, and three foresaw a 25-basis point increase.

;

;Banks might decide not to increase prime rates to help protect the nascent economic rebound, said Louis Tse Ming-kwong, managing director of Wealthy Securities in Hong Kong, one of the two analysts who is banking on a status quo next week.

;

;A 12.5-basis point increase will add HK$351, or 1.6 per cent, to HK$22,803 in monthly instalments on a typical HK$5 million, 30-year mortgage loan, according to mReferral, a local mortgage broker.

;

;HSBC, BOCHK and Hang Seng Bank kept the rates they charge their best customers unchanged at 5.75 per cent in June. Standard Chartered and Bank of East Asia held their rates at 6 per cent. The Fed paused in June to assess the impact of its successive hikes since the March 2022 lift-off.

;

;The Hong Kong Monetary Authority manages its base rate in lockstep with the Fed's policy decision, to help preserve the local currency's peg to the US dollar under its Linked Exchange Rate System.

;

;A stronger-than-expected US economy will allow the Fed to remain “hawkish” and tame inflation closer to its 2 per cent long-term target, according to KGI Asia assistant vice-president of investment strategy Raymond Mok.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 07:50:05 +0800 New service allows female cancer patients in Hong Kong to preserve ovarian tissue, giving them hope of having children in futurehttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3228003/new-service-allows-female-cancer-patients-hong-kong-preserve-ovarian-tissue-giving-them-hope-having?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 07:00;
;;

;Female cancer patients can now choose to preserve their ovarian tissue as a means to regain their reproductive ability after their recovery, with a university in Hong Kong providing the service for the first time in the city.

;

;Cancer patients in urgent need of treatment cannot afford to undergo embryo or egg freezing which requires time to stimulate the ovaries, while those who are still children have not undergone puberty to produce eggs.

;

;Dr Jacqueline Chung Pui-wah, associate professor of Chinese University's department of obstetrics and gynaecology, said ovarian tissue cryopreservation was now available at its assisted reproductive technology unit since early June, offering such patients hope.

;

;Covid increases risk of pregnancy complications, universities in Hong Kong find

;

;“Before the patients undergo any kind of chemotherapy or treatment that can affect their reproductive ability, we can carry out surgery to extract ovarian tissue for preservation,” she said.

;

;“If in the future, they wish to have children after their recovery, we can carry out another operation to transplant the tissue on the ovary surface so that they can reproduce again.”

;

;Chung's team had been assessing the feasibility of implementing ovarian tissue cryopreservation in Hong Kong since 2019.

;

;The researchers collected and froze 52 ovarian tissue samples from 12 patients, aged 29 to 41, which were later transplanted into 34 mice. It was found that most of the tissue remained viable after transplant.

;

;The research findings were published in the Hong Kong Medical Journal in February.

;

;Chung said ovarian tissue cryopreservation had been offered in countries such as Singapore, Thailand and the United States for about 15 years and more than 130 babies had been born from the method. But Hong Kong had only provided sperm, egg or embryo cryopreservation in the past.

;

;“But freezing embryos and eggs requires time. Ovary stimulation has to be carried out according to the menstruation cycle. Two to three weeks has to be reserved for the procedure,” she said.

;

;“But some female patients have to start their chemotherapy immediately, which will make them unsuitable for the procedure.”

;

;She added that ovary stimulation would also increase hormone levels, which might lead to further growth or spread of the cancer.

;

;Chung said after the ovarian tissue was transplanted back to the patient, the chance of getting pregnant would depend on factors such as the woman's age, uterus health and the quality of the embryo.

;

;Chinese University's biobank certified, boosting Hong Kong biomedical hub plans

;

;David Chan Yiu-leung, assistant professor in the department, said a technique called slow freezing had been applied to preserve ovarian tissue.

;

;It is different from vitrification, commonly used in sperm, egg and embryo cryopreservation, which requires a faster rate of freezing.

;

;“As ice has a bigger volume than water, what we are most worried about is that ice will form in the cells during the freezing process and may make the cells burst,” he said.

;

;He explained that during slow freezing, water in the cells would be extracted and the tissue would be stored in a minus 200 degrees Celsius (minus 328 degrees Fahrenheit) environment.

;

;“As cells in ovarian tissue are 1,000 times smaller than eggs, we need to apply the slow freezing method so the tissue can be better preserved,” he said.

;

;The researchers said patients aged 35 or under would be eligible for the service and they were looking for subsidies to support their pilot scheme.

;

;The service would cost at least HK$30,000 to HK$40,000 (US$5,118) with additional charges for surgery and medicines needed depending on the patient's situation and the number of years of cryopreservation.

;

;She said, based on overseas research, it was possible that the ovarian tissue extracted before the cancer treatment could contain cancerous cells, so pathologists would examine the tissue before transplant.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 07:20:04 +0800 In Vietnam, Hanoi’s incense artisans keep a ‘core’ 100-year tradition alivehttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/3228033/vietnam-hanois-incense-artisans-keep-core-100-year-tradition-alive?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 07:00;
;;

;In Quang Phu Cau village, an hour south of Hanoi, Nguyen Dinh Vinh looks out over a sea of crimson. In the courtyard before him, tens of thousands of incense sticks appear in bundles – like explosions of burgundy, maroon and ruby – as they dry in the intense midday sun.

;

;“Everyone in Quang Phu Cau makes incense,” Dinh Vinh said, as he surveyed the mesmerising array of reddened bamboo before him in the visitor centre. “We even had to hire workers from other places.”

;

;In front of the entrance gate, a single joss stick smoulders, its fragrant smoke curling into the air. Worshippers burn aromatic incense throughout Vietnam, especially in Buddhist temples, where the sweet-scented smoke helps to ferry pleas for prosperity up to the heavenly precincts.

;

;The villagers have made the joss sticks here for more than a century. On average, workers in this cottage industry collect 200 tonnes of material and produce 50 tonnes of incense every month.

;

;The result is a hypnotic assembly of dyed bamboo bundles that can bring in as many as five hundred visitors every day on the weekend, according to Dinh Vinh, who is now 65, but started making incense when he was just six years old.

;

;In the past, workers in the village split the wooden sticks by hand when making joss sticks, but these days, they use machines.

;

;“It takes many stages to make incense,” Dinh Vinh said. “First, you have to go to the forest to gather bamboo. Then, you take it to the workshop and whittle it down into incense sticks. After that, we dye the incense before dipping it in a flavoured pink paste … and leaving it out to dry for a few days.”

;

;Vietnamese migrants fill Romania's worker crunch but face risk of exploitation

;

;The incense sticks' fragrance comes from combinations of ingredients, including agarwood, cedar, wormwood, patchouli, rosemary, and cinnamon. The scent is tailored to suit different regions of the country.

;

;Once ready, the incense sticks are sold throughout Vietnam and exported to numerous countries around the world. “Our biggest customers are India, Nepal, and other Asian countries,” he said. “We do not export to China because the Chinese also produce incense.”

;

;Depending on their experience, workers can earn between 5 million and 8 million Vietnamese Dong per month, or between US$210 and US$340.

;

;More than 300 families make incense in the village all year round, but they are especially busy before Lunar New Year when temples across the country are thronged by visitors.

;

;Nguyen Thi Vinh, a septuagenarian incense maker, said: “I am 71 years old this year, but I still continue to make incense. I've been doing this job for 60 years now since I was just over 10 years old.”

;

;“I have four children – three boys and one girl. There are four people in my family who make incense,” she said. “This profession means a lot to us. Thanks to this trade, many people know about our village, and we are able to maintain this profession for future generations.”

;

;Phan Thi Thu Hang, aged 34, said she separates about 200kg of incense sticks into small bundles weighing about two or three kilograms, which are then ready to be dipped in paste, dried, and sold. She adds, however, that “making incense does not only relate to money but has spiritual significance”.

;

;Vietnamese maintain a firm belief in the afterlife and ancestor worship. There is an altar in every home, and it is almost always topped with burning incense, offerings, and flowers.

;

;Due to falling incomes, Dinh Vinh worries that younger generations are losing interest in the profession, yet he does not think the trade will disappear. “Lighting incense to remember our lost parents, our deceased ancestors, is a core element of the spiritual life of the Vietnamese people,” he said.

;

;Vietnamese burn incense to commemorate their ancestors on special occasions including holidays, death anniversaries, family reunions, and the Lunar New Year.

;

;“What has become a tradition cannot be lost,” Dinh Vinh said, before adding simply: “Our ancestors have practised this tradition for thousands of years.”
